Unauthorized modifications detected in t.Data: Windows Event ID 4688; Windows Event ID 4656
Unauthorized modifications detected in t.Action: Monitor Windows Event ID 4688 for process creation events with command lines indicating low-level disk access or tools. Monitor Event ID 4656 for attempts to gain raw handle access to physical drives (e.g., \\.\PhysicalDriveX). Identify patterns or outliers in process execution frequency (descriptive statistics) correlated with system restarts or unusual shutdown events.

Unauthorized creation or modification of.Data: Windows Event ID 4663; Windows Event ID 4656
Unauthorized creation or modification of.Action: Monitor Windows Event ID 4663 and 4656 for audit events targeting known system file paths within the EFI System Partition. Identify processes initiating these access attempts. Analyze access patterns over time (time series analysis) for unusual spikes or activity outside of expected system updates.

Activity indicative of low-level disk ac.Data: Windows Event ID 4688; Windows Event ID 4656
Activity indicative of low-level disk ac.Action: Monitor Windows Event ID 4688 for processes attempting low-level disk writes or using disk-editing tools (e.g., `dd`, `debug.exe`, specific disk utility commands). Correlate with Windows Event ID 4656 for attempts to gain raw handle access to physical drives (e.g., '\\.\PhysicalDrive0'). Use correlation analysis to identify sequences where processes request raw disk access (4656) shortly before or during execution of suspicious disk-related commands (4688). Flag this sequence as potential MBR/VBR tampering activity.

Unusual network connections originating.Action: Filter Zeek conn.log for connection attempts occurring within a short window (e.g., 5-10 minutes) after system startup, potentially before standard user logons. Identify connections originating from unusual internal sources (processes not typically network-active at boot) or destined for external IPs/ports not associated with standard boot-time services (e.g., DNS, NTP, update servers). Use time series analysis to identify recurring early-boot connections. Monitor Windows Event ID 4688 for processes executed with high privileges very early in the boot sequence that initiate network connections and correlate with Zeek logs.
